attributes.comment:
My family is in the process of adopting a Guatemalan child. As you undoubtedly
know, the international adoption process is very involved and expensive. The
proposed fee increases will place undue pressure on adoptive families who are
already experiencing the financial burdens associated with international adoption.

While I understand that increasing fees are "normal and customary" for a variety of
services in life, I expect that with increased fees we will receive increased levels of
service. The US government needs to staff the USCIS offices at level that will
enable the personnel to expedite orphan petitions. Although my USCIS office
(Tampa, FL) processed our I-600A and issued a subsequent I-171 rather quickly
(and efficiently), there is a wide array of time frames for this service throughout the
country. Depending on one's residency, this can vary by as much as 6
months...during which our children are growing older waiting for their final
adoptions. Also, obtaining the Certificiate of Citizenship can now sometimes take
1 year after the child enters the US as our adopted child.

In closing, my position is that it's acceptable to me to shoulder a fee increase as
long as I know that the US will use the increased fees to bolster the
staff/resources necessary to process our applications more quickly and efficiently.
The current inefficiencies experienced by some families around the country are
totally unacceptable.

Thank you.

Lisa Buonarosa
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Lisa Buonarosa
